title: Serial killer Dennis Nilsen spent his final hours in ‘excruciating pain’
text:
Dennis Nilsen (right) after he was jailed for at least 25 years at the Old Bailey in 1983 (Picture: PA)

Notorious serial killer Dennis Nilsen spent his final hours in ‘excruciating pain’ and lying in his own filth before dying behind bars.

Nilsen, 72, was 34 years into a life sentence before his death at HMP Full Sutton last May.

An inquest at Hull Coroner’s Court was told he suffered a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm causing massive internal bleeding.

Despite successful emergency surgery Nilsen died on May 12 having been unable to cope with the blood loss and stress of the lengthy surgery.

Known as the Muswell Hill Murderer, he is believed to have killed as many as 15 men, most of them homosexuals, after luring them back to his north London home.

The civil servant and former policeman murdered and dismembered as many as 15 young men at his homes in North London (Picture: SWNS)

Nilsen’s killing spree was discovered by chance after he blocked the drains flushing away remains (Picture: PA)

During his killing spree in the late 1970s and early 1980s, Nilsen would befriend his victims in pubs and bars in London before bringing them into his flat.

After killing them, either by strangling or drowning, he would bathe, dress and sit with their corpses, often carrying out sex acts with them, before dismembering the bodies.

His crimes were discovered by chance when a drain outside his home on Cranley Gardens became clogged with human remains he had tried to flush away.

Nilsen was jailed for life in 1983 with a recommendation he serve a minimum of 25 years on six counts of murder and two of attempted murder.

The sentence was later upgraded to a whole-life tariff.

Nilsen’s medical cause of death was given as a pulmonary embolism and retroperitoneal haemorrhage, linked to the ruptured aneurysm.

Coroner Paul Marks recorded his verdict simply as: ‘Dennis Andrew Nilsen died of natural causes.’

The coroner said: ‘Although he would not often talk to staff and he did not appear to have any close inmates or associates, he got on well and appeared to be a good prisoner.’

Suzanne Birch, a prison officer, said Nilsen would spend his time wandering around the wing and typing letters on his typewriter.

‘He had no close friends that he would talk to in the prison,’ she added.

Recalling the morning he was taken ill, Ms Birch said: ‘His cell bell sounded, he had never used it in the time I’d been working there.

‘He was hunched over and said he was in excruciating pain in his stomach.’

Nilsen (left) leaving Highgate Magistrates Court (Picture: PA)

Nilsen’s sentence was later upgraded to a whole life tariff (Picture: S&G and Barratts/EMPICS Archive)

His condition was not initially deemed serious enough to send him to hospital and he returned to his cell.

But paramedics were called at 5pm. They found him looking ashen-faced and discovered a ‘pulsing abdominal mass’.

It also stated that Nilsen had been left to ‘lay in his own faeces, deteriorating for two-and-a-half hours’ after rejecting the opportunity to be seen for longer in the healthcare wing on the morning of May 10 last year.

Lisa Noble, the head of healthcare at Full Sutton, said Nilsen had been reluctant to engage previously with healthcare assistants in the prison.

‘He did not particularly like healthcare, and he did not particularly like healthcare staff,’ she told the day-long hearing.

The inquest heard how, like all men over the age of 65, Nilsen was offered an abdominal aortic aneurysm screening on the NHS, but turned it down.

Professor Marks was told how the chances of the aneurysm being fatal would have been significantly reduced had it been discovered at a screening before it had ruptured.
